## z-Scores and Location  

Raw scores provide very little information by themselves 

Ex. Terrence got 34 points on the test. Did he do well?  

The mean and standard deviation provide a context with which to interpret the raw score.  

Ex. Archibaldâ€™s class average was 75 points with a 2 point standard deviation. His score of 34 is not very good.  

z-scores tell us where an x value is in relation to the mean and standard deviation with one number.  

 

## Z-scores  

Signed (+ or -) number  

The sign tells you whether the x value is above the mean (positive) or below the mean (negative)  

The number tells you the amount of standard deviations between the raw score and the mean of the distribution  

Ex: What does a z-score of ________ mean:  -1?  +2?  -3?

## Z-scores as a Standard Distribution  

z-scores do not change the shape of the original distribution or the location of a score relative to others 

When x values are transformed into z-scores, the resulting distribution: 

The mean is always zero  

The standard deviation is always one  

Most z-scores are between z = -2.00 and z = +2.00 

## Z-scores and Locations 

As descriptive statistics, describe exactly where an individual is located 

As inferential statistics, determine whether a sample is representative of its population  

## Z-scores and Samples 

Z-scores are standardized, so we can compare different distributions.
